items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.22 m and is falling slowly.  The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.14 m and is stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load if this level exceeds 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney has been decreasing throughout yesterday, 01/11/21, into today. We are continuing to monitor the situation closely.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Wednesday, 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Water levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses as a result of recent heavy rain. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further light showers are expected today, Tuesday 02/11/2021, however we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. We are monitoring the situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain high at the Low Nibthwaite gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Dunnerdale, Duddon Bridge, Broughton-in-Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Soutergate, Coniston, Ulverston, Dalton-in-Furness and Barrow-in-Furness areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Duddon, Kirkby Pool, Soutergate Beck, Church Beck, Yewdale Beck, Coniston Water, River Crake, Town Beck, Dragley Beck, Poaka Beck, Mill Beck and their tributaries. Further light showers are expected today Tuesday 02/11/2021.  We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels will remain high on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to recent rainfall. Consequently, risk of flooding to low lying land and roads remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. Further light showers are expected today, Tuesday 02/11/2021. This will keep levels high on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high as a result of recent rainfall, although they are now falling slowly.  These include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Further light showers are expected today, Tuesday 02/11/2021. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwent Water remains high following recent heavy rainfall, although it is now beginning to fall slowly. Further light showers are expected today, Tuesday 02/11/2021. Areas that continue to be at risk of flooding include low-lying land bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Wednesday 03/11/2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 02/11/21.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries.  Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Wednesday, 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.31 m and is falling slowly. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.55 m and is falling slowly. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Pumping is now taking place at Currymoor pumping station, as well as Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. The two Currymoor pumps will run while river Tone levels allow, to avoid water spilling back into the Moor.  No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Wednesday, 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are falling but remain above the Flood Alert threshold at the Sherborne Lake river gauge.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 02/11/21. Areas most at risk are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We are monitoring the situation constantly. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 13:00 tomorrow, Wednesday 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Flooding is continuing. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00 on 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Stour, River Lodden, River Shreen

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold along the River Cole and Dorcan Brook. The forecast is for a dry day (02/11/21). 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be aware of standing water on the floodplain and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. The forecast is for dry weather over the next few days. 
Please avoid contact with flood water and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields and rural roads near Fittleworth during Tuesday. However, the Western Rother has now peaked and the river level is slowly falling. With dry weather forecast for the next 5 days, we expect water levels to return to near normal in Fittleworth by Friday 05/11/2021. In Liss, Sheet, Iping, Stedham, Midhurst and Lodsbridge the river level is already normal. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water, which can conceal hidden dangers. We will continue to monitor river levels and forecasts. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on the Rivers Evenlode and Glyme. The forecast is for a dry night (02/11/21). Levels are expected to continue falling overnight and tomorrow following drier conditions.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be aware of standing water on the floodplain and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.

Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels are now falling at the Bradford on Avon river gauge following heavy rainfall over the weekend. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated Wednesday 03/11/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels are steady but continue to be high at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall over the last few days. Consequently, there is still risk of flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning 03/11/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 02/11/21, or as the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen at the Great Somerford river gauge, following heavy rainfall over the weekend, with no further rise currently forecasted.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We continue to monitor the situation. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No property flooding is expected.
No further rainfall is forecast.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Llanymynech river gauge peaked at 3.98m, 07:30 yesterday morning. At 17:00 on 02/11/2021 Cae Howel river gauge was 3.5m and steady. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, and avoid low lying footpaths near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 on 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes

items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Lower Dorset Stour.
Areas most at risk include farms at Sturminster Marshall, Cowgrove, Shops in Wimborne, Mill Street in Corfe Mullen, Bridge House Hotel in Ferndown, Brecon Close, Ringwood Road, Throop Road in Bournemouth, Barrack Road and Willow Way in Christchurch.
River levels are expected to remain high and flooding of properties will continue.
No further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are rising at the Throop and Iford Bridge gauge.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high at the Farndon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, we believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington today, on Tuesday 2nd November 2021. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Please be aware that access to Townfield Lane could be cut off due to high river levels. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels, and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, be aware of your surroundings, and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow, on Wednesday 3rd November, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Ouse remains in force as river levels in York are high due to heavy rainfall upstream in the Pennines over the last few days. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south, as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Levels in York are continuing to fall and we currently expect to remove this alert on Wednesday morning, 03/11/2021. Please see GOV.UK website for the latest river levels and forecast for York. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby remains in force as river levels in York are high due to heavy rainfall upstream in the Pennines over the last few days. Areas near the River Ouse with low-lying land are expected to be most affected, particularly the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. The river level in Naburn at 20:00 on Tuesday 02/11/2021 is 2.2m and levels are continuing to fall slowly. Levels downstream at Selby Westmill are not currently of concern. No significant rainfall is expected in the next couple of days. We will continue to monitor levels closely and currently expect to remove this alert on Wednesday morning 03/11/2021. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Please see GOV.UK website for the latest river levels. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
No property flooding is expected.
Further showery rain is forecast through Tuesday but this is not expected to cause river levels to rise further.
River levels are now falling steadily, but still remain quite high in some locations and a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. Levels remain high in the headwaters of the River Derwent as a result of rainfall over the weekend. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected during Tuesday 2nd November and Wednesday 3rd November. Areas most at risk are low-lying land and roads around Low Marishes. Levels here are currently falling but further rain is forecast for Wednesday and Thursday 4th November, and levels are forecast to rise in response to this rain. Levels in Malton are not currently of concern. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Wednesday 3rd November, or as the situation changes. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 03/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 00:45 on 03/11/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 112 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 03/11/21, or as the situation changes.
